discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I took this exam but only about 10 out of 40 questions were in this list

Selected Answer: D
D, it will not look at CN or SAN while it can see the SNI

Selected Answer: D
FortiGate, by default, evaluates the SNI (Server Name Indication) field in the SSL/TLS handshake for certificate inspection. The SNI is compared against rules in the web filter or policies to determine access permissions or actions. It does not prioritize the CN (Common Name) field from the certificate unless explicitly configured to do so. This aligns with standard behavior where the SNI is used for identifying the target host when dealing with HTTPS traffic
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/Support-Forum/website-access-problems/m-p/266814

choices.B: FortiGate uses the CN information from the Subject field in the server certificate.
choices.A: FortiGate closes the connection because this represents an invalid SSL/TLS configuration.
choices.C: FortiGate uses the first entry listed in the SAN field in the server certificate.
choices.D: FortiGate uses the SNI from the user’s web browser.

questions.question_text:
Consider the scenario where the server name indication (SNI) does not match either the common name (CN) or any of the subject alternative names (SAN) in the server certificate.
Which action will FortiGate take when using the default settings for SSL certificate inspection?

choices.A: Remote registry is not running on the workstation.
choices.D: The user’s status shows as “not verified” in the collector agent.
choices.B: The FortiGate firmware version is not compatible with that of the collector agent.
choices.E: A firewall is blocking traffic to port 139 and 445.
choices.C: DNS resolution is unable to resolve the workstation name.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
1. Active users with a status of “not verified” are also a common problem. That status is normal after a user has logged out. However, it is not normal for a user that is still logged in.
2. A firewall is blocking traffic to port 139 and 445
3. The workstation remote registry service is not running

choices.C: The local FortiGate is the BDR.
choices.A: The local FortiGate is not a DROther.
choices.D: The network type connecting the local Fortigate and OSPF neighbor 0.0.0.10 is point-to-point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Page 430 of the Network Securty Support Engineer Study Guide: The response of the 'get router info ospf neighbor' command displays a dash after the state if the neighbor is in a point-to-point network.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit, which contains partial output from an IKE real-time debug.
//IMG//

The administrator does not have access to the remote gateway.
Based on the debug output, which configuration change can the administrator make to the local gateway to resolve the phase 1 negotiation error?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Incoming proposal lists SHA_256 for encryption, which is not selected locally, cipher suites don't match

choices.A: In the phase 1 proposal configuration, add AESCBC-SHA2 to the list of encryption algorithms.
choices.B: In the phase 1 proposal configuration, add AES256-SHA256 to the list of encryption algorithms.
choices.C: In the phase 1 proposal configuration, add AES128-SHA128 to the list of encryption algorithms.
choices.D: In the phase 1 network configuration, set the IKE version to 2.

questions.question_text: What are two functions of automation stitches? (Choose two.)

choices.B: You can create automation stitches to run diagnostic commands and attach the results to an email message when CPU or memory usage exceeds specified thresholds.
choices.A: You can configure automation stitches on any FortiGate device in a Security Fabric environment.
choices.C: An automation stitch configured to execute actions sequentially can take parameters from previous actions as input for the current action.
choices.D: You can set an automation stitch configured to execute actions in parallel to insert a specific delay between actions.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
A: must be configured on root
B: correct
c: Chaining Actions: In scenarios where one action must be completed before the next one begins, you can enforce a sequence. This is crucial when the outcomes of previous actions determine the subsequent steps.
D: you can configure a delay for an action (to wait fo a system or prozess coming up) but not in parallel

Selected Answer: BC
Ah forget that, parallel actions cannot be delayed. BC

Selected Answer: BD
C I don't think is correct as I've never really seen them work that way (taking output from previos steps), but I'm 100% sure you can add delay between actions, so BD

Selected Answer: BC
Page 145 of Network Security Support Engineer Study Guide: Because this workflow is part of the Security Fabrik, you can set up stitches for any device in the Security Fabric.
If you configure stitches in a Security Fabric, you must configure them on the root Fortigate

Selected Answer: AB
Page 145 of Network Security Support Engineer Study Guide: Because this workflow is part of the Security Fabrik, you can set up stitches for any device in the Security Fabric.

Selected Answer: BC
Correct should be B & C
